--- title: Picking a fantasy football team date: 2023-09-21 date-modified: today categories: [football, optimization, statistics] --- [Cartola FC](http://cartola.globo.com) is a fantasy football league following the Brazilian Championship A Series. Cartola offers a public API to access data for the current round. A couple of years ago, I created a script to automate data retrieval to a [repository](https://github.com/assuncaolfi/tophat/tree/main), which now hosts comprehensive historical data since 2022. In this post, I will delve into the data for the 2022 season, formulate a mixed integer linear program to pick the optimal team, and present initial concepts for forecasting player scores. ## The rules You begin the season with a budget of C$ 100 (C$ stands for Cartoletas, the game’s paper currency). Each round is preceded by a market session, where players are assigned a value $v$. You are tasked with forming a team of 11 players plus a coach, all within your budget and adhering to a valid formation $f \in \mathcal{F}$. A captain must be chosen from among the players, excluding the coach. The market is available until the round starts. Players then earn scores $s$, based on their real-life match performances. Your team's score is the aggregate of your players' scores, with your captain’s score doubled in the 2022 season. Following the conclusion of the round, player values are recalibrated based on performance -— with increases for scores above their average and decreases for below-average performances. Your budget for the next round is your previous budget, plus the sum of your players' value variations. ## Data wrangling First, let's talk about data structures. Each round has a market, and each market is a set of players. A player is a structure like this: ::: {#cell-data-wrangling-players .cell execution_count=1} ::: {#data-wrangling-players .cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html} 
Player(
│   round=0,
│   id=42234,
│   games=0,
│   position=1,
│   average=0.0,
│   value=10.0,
│   score=0.0,
│   appreciation=0.0,
│   minimum=4.53
)

However, for our analysis, we are only interested in players that actually played a game in the round. Each player has a `status` field that is supposed to indicate whether they will participate in the round. However, I've noticed this field is often inacurate, probably because this field is updated before the `round` is. One solution is to keep only rows where there is an increase in the number of `games` the player has played: ::: {#cell-data-wrangling-round-participation-example .cell execution_count=5} ::: {#data-wrangling-round-participation-example .cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: ## Team picking ### Problem How to pick the best team in a market? For each formation $f \in \mathcal{F}$, solve: $$ \begin{equation*} \begin{array}{ll@{}ll} \text{maximize} & \displaystyle \hat{\textbf{s}}^T \textbf{x}, & \textbf{x} \in \{\textbf{0}, \textbf{1}\} \\ \text{subject to} & \displaystyle \textbf{v}^T \textbf{x} \leq b \\ & \displaystyle \textbf{P}^T \textbf{x} = f, \\ \end{array} \end{equation*} $$ where $\textbf{x}$ is a variable vector of player picks; $\hat{\textbf{s}}$ is the vector of predicted player scores; $b$ is the available budget for the round; $\textbf{P}$ is the matrix of dummy-encoded player formations. Finally, take the solution with the highest objective. ::: {#team-picking-problem .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np import pulp class Problem(BaseModel): scores: List[float] values: List[float] budget: float positions: List[List[int]] formations: List[Formation] def solve(self) -> List[pulp.LpSolution]: formations = [list(f.model_dump().values()) for f in self.formations] problems = [self.construct(f) for f in formations] [p.solve(pulp.COIN(msg=False)) for p in problems] objectives = [p.objective.value() for p in problems] best = np.argmax(np.array(objectives)) solution = problems[best] variables = [v.value() for v in solution.variables()] picks = np.array(variables) return picks def construct(self, formation: List[int]) -> pulp.LpProblem: n = len(self.scores) m = len(formation) problem = pulp.LpProblem("team_picking", pulp.LpMaximize) indexes = ["pick_" + str(i).zfill(len(str(n))) for i in range(n)] picks = [pulp.LpVariable(i, cat=pulp.const.LpBinary) for i in indexes] problem += pulp.lpDot(picks, self.scores) problem += pulp.lpDot(picks, self.values) <= self.budget for i in range(m): problem += pulp.lpDot(picks, self.positions[i]) == formation[i] return problem ``` ::: ### Backtesting By solving the team picking problem in all rounds, we can backtest our performance in the 2022 season. First, let's get $\mathcal{F}$ for 2022: ::: {#cell-team-picking-formations .cell execution_count=11} ::: {#team-picking-formations .cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html} 
[
│   Formation(goalkeeper=1, defender=3, winger=0, midfielder=4, forward=3, coach=1),
│   Formation(goalkeeper=1, defender=3, winger=0, midfielder=5, forward=2, coach=1),
│   Formation(goalkeeper=1, defender=2, winger=2, midfielder=3, forward=3, coach=1),
│   Formation(goalkeeper=1, defender=2, winger=2, midfielder=4, forward=2, coach=1),
│   Formation(goalkeeper=1, defender=2, winger=2, midfielder=5, forward=1, coach=1),
│   Formation(goalkeeper=1, defender=3, winger=2, midfielder=3, forward=2, coach=1),
│   Formation(goalkeeper=1, defender=3, winger=2, midfielder=4, forward=1, coach=1)
]
``` ::: ::: Now, starting with C$ 100, for each round we: 1. Pick the best team; 2. Add the sum of the team player's appreciation to our budget. ::: {#team-picking-backtest .cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} from typing import Callable def backtest( players: pl.DataFrame, predict: Callable, initial_budget: float = 100.0 ) -> pl.DataFrame: rounds = players.get_column("round").max() budget = [None] * rounds teams = [None] * rounds budget[0] = initial_budget for round in range(rounds): if round > 0: budget[round] = budget[round - 1] + appreciation data = players.filter(pl.col("round") < round + 1) candidates = players.filter(pl.col("round") == round + 1) candidates = predict(data, candidates) problem = Problem( scores=candidates.get_column("prediction"), values=candidates.get_column("value"), positions=candidates.get_column("position").to_dummies(), budget=budget[round], formations=formations, ) picks = problem.solve() team = candidates.filter(picks == 1) teams[round] = team appreciation = team.get_column("appreciation").sum() teams = pl.concat(teams) return teams ``` ::: Let's start with a couple of hypothetical backtests, by using data that is not available prior to the round. Looking back at the 2022 season, we already know all player scores. Let's set $ \hat{s} = s$ for all rounds and backtest this strategy. To test this hypothesis, we backtest campaign with unlimited budget from the start: ::: {#cell-team-picking-backtest-score-minimum .cell execution_count=15} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=151} ![](index_files/figure-html/team-picking-backtest-score-minimum-output-1.png){#team-picking-backtest-score-minimum width=602 height=445} ::: ::: Both strategies are nearly identical, which is evidence that focusing on appreciation is not so important if we have accurate predictions for the scores. https://medium.com/cartolaanalitico/a-fórmula-de-valorização-8064b82b0f0 To put the Score strategy into perspective, [the 2022 season champion had a total score of 3434.37](https://ge.globo.com/cartola/noticia/2022/12/03/cartola-2022-com-larga-vantagem-mosquito-bar-8-vence-liga-premiada-meliuz-e-fatura-r-20-mil.ghtml).
